text: haha, a guy would've been the worst person to ask that question to. Heterosexual traditions are practically hard-coded into culture, and demand men make the first move. And it's not like this is an explicit rule, women could make the first move, but what's also hard-coded is that a woman making the first move signifies a failure on the guy's part, which intrinsically makes it a big no-no. Guys however are secretly desperate to be in that situation, and would gladly accept, it's just that many women would rather die of old age than endure the embarrassment of having to ask a guy on a date because he's too oblivious to do it first. It's made even less likely because, as the subject of male pursuit, women don't need to look far to find a guy who will. So she'd have to go way out of her way to break that mold. It's a cultural impasse.
author: @z-beeblebrox

text: I'm not a lesbian, but I honestly felt more flattered being approached by a woman. I had a friend in junior high who was gay and told me she was attracted to me in the beginning. There's just something about one kind of person who takes extra time in their appearance, smells nice, has their stuff together, and carries themselves with confidence telling you they like you for the same reasons. It gives you a pep in your step. Meanwhile, guys hit on you like "woman hot" without understanding the level of effort we put into ourselves on the daily.
author: @loliver9660

text: As a woman I can say turning down women who approach me has always been pleasant and SAFE. No offense has EVER been taken and my day has NEV^been ruined afterwards ‚ù§

author: @KingRitoru364

text:
As someone who presents as male (non-binary but 6'4" and not femme), I always feel so rough when getting turned down. I try to look nice, smell good, be polite, and respect social boundaries and such, but because men are so toxic and disrespectful especially up here in the north, I think women have just taken to having this ice queen approach to a turn down where they make you feel like a creep just for asking if they want to dance. Like...at a dance event. You know...where you're supposed to dance.

I try never to take it personally, because I know if they knew me they'd know I'm kind, generous, not out to be a threat or make them have a bad night, not going to hurl insults at them or w/e, but it just seems like sometimes the gals in New England are out for blood when they turn you down and I'm like damn I'm just trying to have a nice conversation and get to know somebody pretty, sheesh.

I wish men would just be better and then we'd start to untie the whole stupid Gordian knot and probably everybody would have a better time when they go out.
author: @d.w.stratton4078

text: Sooo funny story. In the Army I had a lot of friends who were LGBQT and one of them could not read a room at all. She ended up getting a really hot roommate, she looked like Beyonc√©, and she became infatuated but the roommate was straight. I think she tried hooking up with her for months despite her having a boyfriend, in think she actually said a couple of times that they were just good friends despite everyone telling her they were together. Anyways things went down hill fast when my friend brought over one of her girl friends, the girlfriend is someone who wouldn‚Äôt describe as attractive, and tried fixing the boyfriend up with her so she could have the roommate. After this the roommate and the Boyfriend went to a drive through chapel off post just so they could move out of the barracks and I don‚Äôt blame them, I think they even had a kid!

text:
IDK why but this brought me back to a memory I'd totally forgot! 10th grade homecoming, this random, annoying ass freshman girl came up to my friend group and caught part of a conversation and asked me, "oh, you're gay?" And I said, "yeah?" in a "what's it to you?" kinda way and she goes, "oh. I'm not." I said, "okay? Good for you?" ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I think it was the first time she considered the fact that being attracted to women ‚â† attracted to every woman you see/meet. 

Weirdly she came up dancing around me at the dance after the game. My best friend and I were both out the Monday after from whiplash-esque pain after going on a certain rollercoaster 13x in one day and when I returned to school Tuesday, that weird rando ran up and hugged me and I'm like, "whoa! Who the fuck are you?!" She announced, "I'm Nikki, from homecoming!" I said, "okay, 'Nikki from homecoming', gtfoff of me!" 
Starting that day, that little pest was outside my classes every time I left one class to go to the next. She walked me to my next class and talked at me the whole way. This lasted about 2 weeks before my patience wore thin and I finally asked, "girl, why are you stalking me?!" She was like, "üò≥ I'm not stalking you!" And then she finally left me alone until my choir xmas concert. I greeted her with, "what's up, stalker?" when she approached me uninvited and she turned red and left me alone for good, finally.
author: @lcoq19
